docs.lead_paragraph: With just a week to go before New York City's not-very-set-in-stone deadline for passing its budget, a state oversight board warned yesterday that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's current plan to balance the budget ''appears to be in jeopardy.'' The New York State Financial Control Board, which took over the city's finances during the fiscal crisis of the 1970's and now monitors its budgets and financial plans, reported that it had identified $1.7 billion in risks in Mr. Bloomberg's plan to close the city's roughly $5 billion budget gap for the 2003 fiscal year, which begins on July 1.

headline.main: State Warns About Risks Jeopardizing City's Budget

docs.abstract: New York State Financial Control Board warns that Mayor Michael Bloomberg's current plan to balance New York City budget 'appears to be in jeopardy'; says it has identified $1.7 billion in risks in Bloomberg's plan to close city's roughly $5 billion budget gap for 2003 fiscal year (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Charges of mob influence and political corruption are nothing new in this blue-collar town, where Al Capone once lived. Still, the fraud trial of Cicero's town president, Betty Loren-Maltese, has stirred the public's interest. While some, like Hatak James, 60, and his wife, Joan, 62, say Ms. Loren-Maltese has done a lot for their town, they are not convinced that she did not have her hand in the cookie jar. The authorities say Ms. Loren-Maltese and seven others stole $10 million in an elaborate scheme involving a mob boss. Still, some residents have mixed emotions.

headline.main: Trial Excites Town Used to Colorful Cases

docs.abstract: Cicero, Ill, long familiar with political corruption, is now watching fraud and racketeering trial of town president Betty Loren-Maltese; photo; federal authorities say she and seven others siphoned off more than $10 million from employee insurance program, using money to buy hotel, horse farm, vacation houses and cars; also accused are former police chief Emil Schullo and former town treasurer Joseph DeChicio (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In an effort to stop doctors from leaving the state because of the high cost of malpractice insurance, Gov. Kenny Guinn, a Republican, announced changes for the Medical Liability Association of Nevada, a state-run company that provides temporary insurance. The revisions include a $250,000 cap on damages for pain and suffering, a possible suit against a Minnesota insurer that dropped nationwide malpractice insurance and an offer to cover doctors for malpractice that occurred while under other policies. Mindy Sink (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | West: Nevada: Plan To Help Doctors On Malpractice Policies

docs.abstract: Nevada Gov Kenny Guinn modifies policies of state-run medical liability association, in effort to keep doctors from leaving state because of high cost of malpractice insurance (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: AARP joined three lawsuits against large drug companies today, saying the companies had kept prices artificially high and thwarted competition from lower-priced generic drugs in violation of federal antitrust laws. The cases involve BuSpar, an anti-anxiety drug made by Bristol-Myers Squibb; K-Dur 20, a potassium supplement made by Schering-Plough; and tamoxifen, a breast cancer medicine sold by AstraZeneca under the name Nolvadex.

headline.main: AARP Joins Three Lawsuits Against Large Drug Companies

docs.abstract: AARP joins three lawsuits accusing large drug companies of keeping prices artificially high and thwarting competition from lower-priced generic drugs in violation of federal antitrust laws; cases involve BuSpar, anti-anxiety drug made by Bristol-Myers Squibb, K-Dur 20, potassium supplement made by Schering-Plough, and tamoxifen, breast cancer drug sold by AstraZeneca under name Nolvadex; industry denies accusation and denounces AARP for joining small army of plaintiffs' lawyers in seeking monetary damages from drug companies (M)
docs.snippet: AARP joined three lawsuits against large drug companies today, saying the companies had kept prices artificially high and thwarted competition from lower-priced generic drugs in violation of federal antitrust laws.    The cases involve BuSpar, an...

docs.lead_paragraph: The chairman and chief executive of the struggling energy company Dynegy, whose departure was announced on Tuesday, is entitled under his contract to a huge severance check -- one that is about $33 million more than he would have made had the company allowed him to serve out the eight months remaining on the contract. Charles L. Watson guided Dynegy from a tiny company into a member of the Fortune 500 and just six months ago appeared to have vaulted it into the top ranks of American business by agreeing to acquire Enron.

headline.main: Dynegy Chief Is Much Richer for Being Forced Out

docs.abstract: Dynegy Inc's ousted chairman and chief executive Charles L Watson is entitled to severance package that is $33 million more than he would have gotten had company allowed him to serve out eight months remaining on his contract; why Dynegy board has decided to take financial hit is not clear; it appears board feels that with investor confidence ebbing, it could not afford to have Watson in charge rest of year; Watson's position has weakened as deal to acquire Enron collapsed and with continued disclosures of questionable accounting practices and trading techniques in energy industry; Dynegy faces accounting investigation by Securities and Exchange Commission; company says this has nothing to do with Watson's departure (M)
docs.snippet: The chairman and chief executive of the struggling energy company Dynegy, whose departure was announced on Tuesday, is entitled under his contract to a huge severance check -- one that is about $33 million more than he would have made had the company...

docs.lead_paragraph: The consensus among Republicans as they wrapped up their convention yesterday is that George E. Pataki is a juggernaut on course to become the fourth New York governor in a century to win a third term. His approval ratings are higher than ever, even among Democrats, and his war chest is brimming with at least $16 million, twice what either of his two Democratic opponents has raised. But the race this year differs greatly from the contests he won in 1994 and 1998. Even his most confident supporters acknowledge that the governor can take nothing for granted in a state where registered Democrats outnumber Republicans five million to three million.

headline.main: The G.O.P. Is Confident, Maybe Too Confident, About the Race

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Cuba's Other Face'' (letter, May 23): The letter writer notes Cuba's low infant mortality and illiteracy rates. I'd like to add that all Cubans get free health care. By contrast, in the United States some 40 million people lack health insurance.
docs.abstract: Letter from Ilya Shlyakhter notes that all Cubans get free health care, while 40 million people in United States lack health insurance; says this shameful gap should be closed before America lectures Cubans on how to run their country (May 23 letter)

docs.lead_paragraph: Two-thirds of the drugs approved from 1989 to 2000 were modified versions of existing drugs or even identical to those already on the market, rather than truly new medicines, according to a new study. The report also said that most of the increased spending on new prescription drugs was on products that the Food and Drug Administration had determined did not provide significant benefits over those already on the market.

headline.main: New Medicines Seldom Contain Anything New, Study Finds

docs.abstract: National Institute for Health Care Management Foundation study shows two-thirds of drugs approved from 1989 to 2000 were modified versions of existing drugs or even identical to those already on market, rather than truly new medicines; also says that most of increased spending on new prescription drugs was on products that Food and Drug Administration had determined did not provide significant benefits over those already on market; Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America, drug industry's trade group, criticizes study, saying that it is 'flawed and misguided'; Richard I Smith, vice president for policy and research at group, says that even if medicine is similar to one already on market, it could still offer many benefits to patients; institute receives 40 percent of its financing from Blue Cross Blue Shield health insurers and has often clashed with pharmaceutical industry because of its reports on rising cost of prescription drugs (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In a show of unity and allegiance to Gov. George E. Pataki, state Republican Party delegates voted unanimously yesterday to designate John J. Faso as their candidate for state comptroller and Dora Irizarry, the first Hispanic woman to be nominated to statewide office, as attorney general. Each was the only candidate nominated. It was a placid contrast to the fractious Democratic State Convention last week, where one of the headliners, Andrew M. Cuomo, refused to appear and other candidates hustled for last-minute votes.

headline.main: Republicans, in a Show of Unity, Vote as One to Nominate Candidates

docs.abstract: New York State Republicans vote unanimously to designate John J Faso as their candidate for state comptroller and Dora Irizarry as attorney general; convention gives strong show of party unity; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In between its strained and sporadic contract talks with the Bloomberg administration, the union representing New York City teachers has quietly been gauging public support for a strike and considering whether and when the city's 80,000 teachers should walk off the job. Last week, the union, the United Federation of Teachers, conducted a telephone poll of 620 city households, asking questions like, ''When you hear that the teachers' union is voting to authorize a possible strike if negotiations do not achieve an acceptable contract, would you say your reaction is mainly sympathetic and understanding or mainly angry and unsympathetic?''

headline.main: City Teachers Union Poll Gauges Public Support for Possible Strike

docs.abstract: Sixty-five percent of respondents in United Federation of Teachers poll say they would be 'sympathetic and understanding' if teachers struck New York City public schools, and 22 percent say they would be angry and unsympathetic; Randi Weingarten, union president, says poll fortifies her belief in all-out effort to win contract she wants; spokesman for Mayor Michael R Bloomberg says mayor is more interested in improving education than responding to polls (M)
